scenes.background: You are leading a project team that has just received an urgent assignment requiring a significant amount of work to be completed within a tight deadline. The team is feeling a lot of pressure, and morale is low, with some members showing signs of frustration and anxiety. Previously, when one of the team members, Alex, said, 'This is impossible! We can't get this done in time,' you responded by encouraging the team to stay focused and work together. During a team meeting, [Monica] slammed her pen on the table and added, 'Even if we try our best, there's no way we can meet this deadline.' [Bob] nodded in agreement, looking equally concerned. You suggested taking a pause to rethink the approach. With the team gathered again, [Monica] leaned back in her chair, crossing her arms, and said, 'So, what’s the new grand plan?' You invited collaborative problem-solving by suggesting, 'Let's brainstorm some ideas together. We need everyone's input to come up with a viable plan.'
scenes.description: [Monica] rolls her eyes and says, 'Brainstorming isn’t going to magically give us more hours in the day.' [Bob] adds, 'I mean, if we’re going to do this, we need concrete steps, not just ideas.'

options.text: Let's start by listing out the specific tasks and see which ones we can delegate or simplify.
options.analysis: You proposed a practical step to address the workload, showing good emotional perception and empathy.

options.text: I understand the concern. Maybe we should re-prioritize our tasks and focus on the most critical ones first.
options.analysis: You acknowledged the team's frustration and suggested a pragmatic step to re-prioritize tasks, demonstrating good self-regulation and motivation.

options.text: We’ve faced tougher deadlines before and succeeded. Let’s focus on what we can control and tackle this head-on.
options.analysis: You focused on motivating the team with a rallying call to action, showing high motivation but lower empathy and emotional perception.
